page.title: 01Mountains East of Bethesda
page.content: The area is predominantly rough grazing for thousands of sheep and a few dozen ponies and feral goats. Several farms have sheep ranges in the area, which is typicallly high pasture except for the valley of Afon Caseg running east-west along the southern boundary of the area. The peaty valley floor, though grazed, has coarser vegetation. The valley mouth has some high enclosed fields. The ridges and slopes are well drained and dry whereas the flatter cols and cwms in between are wetter and peaty. Most of the area is owned by the National Trust. A complex of sheep pens occupies the south slope of Gyrn 647688. The users of the land are exclusively Welsh speaking. A few illdefined footpaths cross the area but in the higher reaches (Bera Bach, Yr Aryg) they are marked at intervals
